node.text: In a bid to chip away at the remaining hesitancy regarding makeup on men, we asked the makeup artist @RaisaFlowers to do a pair of video tutorials demonstrating looks that readers can, she hopes, easily replicate at home. In the one shown here, she realizes a look inspired by the 1998 film “Velvet Goldmine,” with shimmery purple eye shadow and translucent tinted lip balm. The overall effect is meant to be one of high-impact minimalism tempered with subtle playfulness. Visit tmagazine.com for more. Video by Justin French (@frenchgold), styled by @YohanaLebasi. #TBeautyIssue

node.title: Makeup for Men, or Anyone: Full-Face Glam

node.text: As part of T’s Beauty & Luxury issue, the writer @MeganEOGrady explores what makeup means to the growing group of men who have embraced it. Her piece is accompanied by photos of models with faces done by the makeup artist @RaisaFlowers, who, in a bid to make such adornment less intimidating, breaks down her process in a pair of video tutorials, demonstrating what she calls two “simplistic and masculine” looks that readers can, she hopes, easily replicate at home. In one video, she shares tips for creating dewy skin accented with a vivid swipe of color across the lids, and in another, she realizes a more classically glamorous visage with shimmery purple eye shadow and translucent tinted lip balm. The overall effect of both styles is a kind of high-impact minimalism tempered with subtle playfulness. See more on tmagazine.com. Video by Justin French (@frenchgold), styled by @YohanaLebasi. #TBeautyIssue

node.title: Minimal Makeup Looks for Men — or Anyone

node.text: A brief history of how New York’s Sag Harbor became a refuge for African-American families, with testimonials from some of the residents who’ve summered there for much of their lives. Read Sandra E. Garcia's (@s_evangelina) accompanying story on this close-knit community on tmagazine.com. Video by @JoshuaKissi. Produced by Tom Delavan (@tdelavan).

node.title: Long Island's Enduring Black Beachfront Community

node.text: Flip your phone horizontally to watch this video: On Feb. 25 and 26, 2020, T gathered seven established black actresses — all of whom got their start decades ago, working across various mediums — for a group and cover shoot by the photographers @MickaleneThomas and @RacquelChevremont in Los Angeles, California. In it, these women — @HalleBerry, Angela Bassett (@im.angelabassett), @TarajiPHenson, Mary J. Blige (@therealmaryjblige), Lynn Whitfield (@mslynnwhitfield), @ViolaDavis and Kimberly Elise (@ikimberlyelise) — remember their first roles and discuss the solidarity they feel with one another. “We are living in an age in which some of our greatest, most successful actors are black women, near 50 or older, veterans who have fought against an industry that for much of its history would have rather ignored them,” writes @BrianKeithJackson in the accompanying story. Read more on Tmagazine.com. Video by @scottrossfilm.

node.text: Flip your phone horizontally to watch this video: On Oct. 15, 2018, T gathered 32 black American male poets, playwrights and novelists — writers whose work is so crucial to our understanding America itself — at the Brooklyn Historical Society for a group portrait creative directed by @BootsRiley and this accompanying short film by @YvonneMichelleShirley. In it, these men reflect on their experiences and quote from some of their favorite works by black female American writers, whose voices are equally powerful and necessary. As Audre Lorde once said, “We don't only write about ourselves, we use ourselves to illuminate something that we really believe and we really feel.” Read the accompanying story, and why we chose to focus specifically on black men for this piece, on Tmagazine.com. You’ll also find a reading list chosen by these men of their favorite black female writers.

node.title: On Being a Black Male Writer in America

node.text: Around the country, restaurants are expanding their menus of thoughtful, complex, nonalcoholic cocktails to keep pace — especially this month — with a population that’s drinking less. And while these drinks are made for adult palates, they’re also drawing an unexpected fan base: children. T hosted a taste test, inviting children of the magazine’s staff and writers to assess several mocktails at @ReceptionBar.NYC, a modern Korean spot on Manhattan’s Lower East Side. Video by @scottrossfilm.

node.text: #T25Buildings: As an architecture student at Cornell, the Chicago-based artist Amanda Williams (@awstudioart) read and reread the German American painter and designer Josef Albers’s seminal 1963 text “Interaction of Color,” in which he argues that all colors are “relational,” mutable according to those alongside them and to each person’s individual experience. For her “Color(ed) Theory” series, Williams, who was born in the Chicago suburb of Evanston and raised on the city’s South Side, spent two years in the neighborhood of Englewood, also on the South Side, painting condemned houses using a color palette coded with cultural references specific to the Black experience: turquoise became “Ultrasheen,” after the hair conditioner; violet became “Crown Royal Bag,” after the whisky; teal became “Loose Squares/Newport 100,” after the cigarette brand. “There’s not a day that goes by that I don’t think about color,” Williams writes, “as both an artistic medium, and then also as race.” The houses in “Color(ed) Theory” had already ceased to be habitable interiors delimited by walls; Williams made them mnemonics for cultural memory that lawmakers have spent decades trying to erase. Click the link in our bio for T’s full list of the 25 most significant buildings erected or cleverly updated since World War II. Photo by Amanda Williams.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 02, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and brick wall.

node.text: #T25Buildings: Among the buildings selected for T’s list of the 25 most significant works of postwar architecture — which was created by the architects Toshiko Mori (@toshiko.mori), @AnnabelleSelldorf and @VincentVanDuysen; the designer Tom Dixon (@tomdixonstudio); the artist and set designer @EsDevlin; the critic and T contributor @NikilSaval; and Tom Delavan (@tdelavan), T’s design/interiors director — is the Italian Brazilian architect Lina Bo Bardi’s SESC Pompéia in São Paulo, Brazil (1986). In the mid-1970s, when Bo Bardi was commissioned to design a cultural center in a former factory in São Paulo’s neighborhood of Pompéia, adaptive reuse of industrial spaces had yet to enter the architectural mainstream. But Bo Bardi saw in the factory’s saw-tooth roofline and industrial scale a heritage structure no less valuable than the historic buildings that she’d evaluated for damage back in her native Italy in the aftermath of World War II. The factory was owned by a nongovernmental organization called SESC, or Social Service of Commerce, founded by business leaders in 1946 to provide employees with free community spaces. With the aim of preserving that grass-roots vibrancy, Bo Bardi removed the factory’s interior walls, then softened the space with an undulating pool cut into the concrete floor. “I wanted to represent Bo Bardi in one fashion or another,” said Saval. “And I thought I could have chosen her house (Casa de Vidro, 1951; São Paulo), or the São Paulo Museum of Art, but I just think this is a really joyous building: There’s this combination of exuberance and monumentality.” Click the link in our bio for more, and to see the full list. Photos by Nelson Kon.

node.text: #T25Buildings: Once completed, the 38-story Seagram Building (1958) on Park Avenue in Manhattan instantly became one of Ludwig Mies van der Rohe’s most influential works, representing a high point in the history of corporate Modernism. Unsurprisingly, it was selected by T’s eight-person jury as one of the 25 most significant works of postwar architecture. A ground-level plaza occupies roughly half the building’s corner plot, an expression of the bold ideas championed by Phyllis Lambert, a daughter of the Seagram’s C.E.O. Samuel Bronfman, and the director of planning for the project. The sacrifice of valuable space to the public realm permanently changed Manhattan’s urban fabric, inspiring zoning laws that would encourage future developers to push their structures back from the street. As the architect @AnabelleSeldorf said, “Just imagine that you’re building this high-rise and you’re setting it back from the street to create this generous plaza in front. There’s a kind of heroic quality on an urban scale that is very important.” The building has since come to embody the coldness of capitalist power, with countless corporate headquarters copying its irreducible monumentality, but it revolutionized the way that architecture, even at such an imposing scale, could contribute to the lived space of the city below. Click the link in our bio for more, and to see the full list. Image © Ezra Stoller/Esto.

node.text: #T25Buildings: Upon his arrival in Mexico City from Guadalajara in 1936, Luis Barragán worked tirelessly to build his persona as a poet of color and light. While many of his peers were designing hospitals and housing projects on a grand scale, he mostly eschewed such civic engagements, dedicating himself to upscale housing developments and cloistral private homes, none finer than the one he built for himself in 1948, Casa Luis Barragán — which was selected by T’s eight-person jury as one of the 25 most significant works of postwar architecture. Hidden behind a blank wall of plastered concrete, the building turns its back to the street, unveiling itself through a sequence of passages and stairwells that open into spaces of vivid austerity. With its overgrown back garden studded with narcissus and jasmine, Casa Barragán also incorporates landscape and art into its intimate study of atmosphere and proportion. Click the link in our bio for more, and to see the full list. Photo by Magda Biernat/OTTO.

node.text: #T25Buildings: A few months ago, the architects Toshiko Mori (@toshiko.mori), @AnnabelleSelldorf and @VincentVanDuysen; the designer Tom Dixon (@tomdixonstudio); the artist and set designer @EsDevlin; the critic and T contributor @NikilSaval; and Tom Delavan (@tdelavan), T’s design/interiors director, joined T’s features director @KurtSoller via Zoom to talk about postwar architecture. Their goal was to make a list of the 25 most significant buildings that have been erected — or cleverly updated — since World War II. The word “significant” always inspires debate, and there was plenty of disagreement among those assembled, who surfaced projects from all over the world, and that represented all kinds of styles and typologies, though they limited themselves to those still standing. Given the difficulties plaguing our current moment, it’s not surprising that the social concerns related to architecture — the need to provide housing, for instance; the idea that beautiful cities and communities shouldn’t only be built for and by the rich; the urgency of sustainability — were on everyone’s mind, and the panel attempted to be democratic in more straightforward ways, too, choosing projects from every continent except for Antarctica (though, spoiler alert, outer space makes an appearance) and considering the field’s historical inequities, especially in the West, and particularly when it comes to Black architects and women architects. A different list would have emerged from a different group, or even from this same group on a different afternoon. As Selldorf pointed out in a brief moment of frustration with the assignment, “The real trouble is there are more than 25 important buildings.” Nonetheless, the panel came to a kind of agreement, and you can find the full and final list of buildings at the link at our bio. Written by @KurtSoller and Michael Snyder (@mtpsnyder).

node.text: #RoomOfTheDay: Maria Berman and Brad Horn, founders of the New York-based architectural firm Berman Horn Studio, softened their modernist Maine home with traditional and antique furniture. In the sitting room, pictured here, a lacquered floor reflects light throughout the day. From the book “The Maine House” (@themainehouse_thebook), which has photography by @MauraMcEvoy, art direction by Basha Burwell (@basha_oog) and words by @KathleenHackett, and is out now from @vendomepress.

node.text: On the north side of @MatildaGoad’s home in London, tucked in a nook between the kitchen and the living room, is a small courtyard paved with granite cobblestones. The narrow yard, flanked on one side by a clematis-strewn fence, has a distinctly rural feel, partly thanks to a salvaged Butler porcelain sink propped against the left-hand wall that, on a bright day in June, is filled with soaking dahlia tubers and foxgloves ready to be planted. A few steps away, above an old zinc bath that contains hydrangea shrubs, their stems hidden by soleirolia, is a porthole window that affords a view through the living room and to the garden at the back of the house. Many a space-strapped Londoner would have opted to build out into this strip of land, snatching up additional square footage and ramming up against their neighbor’s boundary in the process. “I wanted to shake up what could have been a formulaic layout," says Goad, "creating a sense of discovery even in a small space." To accomplish this, she sought advice from the American-born, London-based garden designer @ButterWakefield. At the link in our bio, the pair share tips for creating an oasis of your own. Written by Ellie Pithers (@ellie_pithers), photo by @CarlottaCardana. #TSummerEntertaining

node.text: Set at the base of the Phoenix Mountain Preserve, the Arizona Biltmore was once a retreat for the 1920s Hollywood jet set. Surrounded by palm trees, this landmark Waldorf Astoria Resort is revered for its Art Deco design — architect Frank Lloyd Wright was the lead consultant for the hotel’s commissioned architect, Albert Chase McArthur. Welcoming a new stage in its history, the property recently reopened after a 15-month renovation, with the Hilton hospitality group tapping design consultants Virserius Studio, the architecture firm PHX Architecture and Jim Smith of Serving the Nation, Inc., to oversee the project, which included a refresh of some of its 701 contemporary guest rooms (luxury cottages and villas among them). Also new to the property is an adults-only pool and a transformed Wright Bar, where the famous tequila sunrise cocktail was originally invented by the bartender Gene Sulit. Click the link in our bio for more. Written by @MichaelaTrimble. #TList

node.text:
@ShingTatChung and Erchen Chang (@leekungman) — the husband-and-wife duo behind London’s beloved Bao restaurants (@bao_london), as well as Xu Teahouse & Restaurant (@xu_london) — often recruit their creative friends as helpers when planning a dinner party. For a recent event at the couple’s Forest Gate home, Harry Darby, the designer and founder of the cocktail and cordial company Gimlet Bar, created the vivid blue drink — a mix of sirop de menthe, J. Bally Rhum Blanc from Martinique and lots of fresh lime juice — that Chang named the paradise, and that opened the evening. The artist and ceramist Anna Hodgson, who has made crockery for Bao since its early days, when it was just a stall at Hackney’s Netil Market, and who moonlights as the manager of the much-loved bar at 40 Maltby Street in Bermondsey, created a wine list that included an orange Jacquère from Savoie and a lightly effervescent red, called Onde Gravitazionali, from the small-batch Piedmontese winemaker Fabio Gea. And Darby and Hodgson collaborated on a playlist, filled with the soft arrangements of the composer Henry Mancini and the jazz harpist Dorothy Ashby, that helped set the mood. “Guests don’t actually like feeling useless while you flap about,” says Chang. “When you enlist their help, they feel like they’ve played an important part in the evening.” Click the link in our bio for more tips from the couple on how to host an intimate, artistic evening with friends. Written by Sophie Bew, photo by Tami Aftab.
#TSummerEntertaining

node.text: Curating the perfect summer dinner party playlist can feel like a daunting task, and even music obsessives can fall into ruts and benefit from others offering up song suggestions. Recently, we asked a range of artists, musicians and other creative types to do just that, and to share a few tips on putting your selections together. “I’ll start off with ‘Clair de Lune’ — it invokes Paris and New York in equal parts, with mixed drinks clinking and obligatory salutations on display,” said the musician John Cale, a co-founder of the Velvet Underground. As you move from cocktails to dinner, try playing something mid-tempo, soulful and longish, like Gram Parsons’s “She” (1973), which, as the guitar slides past the four-minute mark, might subconsciously induce hunger. For the meal itself, keep in mind, as the musician Sharon Van Etten says, that “it’s important to pick songs that don’t take over the conversations. If it’s too loud or bumping, it’s impossible to talk to your friends or sit over dinner in a relaxing way.” Click the link in our bio for an eclectic playlist sure to set a festive mood. Pictured: “Nuit de Noël (Happy-Club)”(1963) © Malick Sidibé. Courtesy of the artist and Jack Shainman Gallery, New York.

node.text: #RoomOfTheDay: Carlo Scarpa's reimagining of ancient public buildings made him an Italian icon, but the 20th-century architect is perhaps best understood through the private homes he designed. In the garden room at the Zentner House, built in the 1960s in Zurich, two ’70s-era paintings by Piero Dorazio hang over a LC4 chaise by Le Corbusier, Pierre Jeanneret and Charlotte Perriand. Photo by @IlariaOrsini.
